newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper futures end up on short-covering.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper futures end up on short-covering.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended up sharply with all contracts closing above the key 20,000-yuan resistance level on Thursday due to short-covering, traders said.
The most active April 1997 contract ended at 20,070 yuan ($2,419) per tonne, rising 450 yuan. It opened at an intra-day low of 19,800 and hit a high of 20,080.
January rose 370 to 20,000, February 370 to 20,000, March 440 to 20,060 and May 450 to 20,100.
Combined volume rose to 66,270 tonnes from 39,710.
Copper opened higher and rose further with most contracts closing at or near their intra-day highs.
Traders said trading was dull early in the session but short-covering emerged in the afternoon on concern about the stockpile data on the London Metal Exchange which will be announced tonight.
"Short position holders were not sure if the stockpile would fall or rise, so they liquidated their positions in order to evade risks," one trader said.
"But heavy selling will pick up immediately if prices fall on the LME tonight," he added.
"Today's technical charts showing the market was oversold also helped copper to recover some of its losses of the past few days," a second trader said.
Analysts given the problems of predicting copper's trend, it was best to take a wait-and-see attitude in the next few days.
Aluminium ended down. The only traded January contract fell 50 yuan to close at 13,850 yuan per tonne with only 60 tonnes traded.
